He has had two separate periods of more than three years' continuous service. He has merited his promotion from labourer to head labourer. In the name of that justice and humanity of which Deputy Dunne speaks, why should I remove him unless I have just cause for doing so? Why should I deny that head labourer the increase in pay to which his promotion entitles him? Why should I refuse him a higher status without just cause? If I find just cause to take disciplinary action I will take it, not for the sake of inflicting a wound but for the sake of the men and for the good of the Department. I have no just cause to take action against this man, and if I deprive him of his pay I would feel compelled to make restitution to him. I am sure the officials I sent down to investigate did not deceive me, and I am bound in conscience and justice not to deprive this man of something he has earned until such time as I get cause to do so. If I find at any time that the men are being unfairly or harshly treated I will take prompt and swift action.
Is it not a fact that when the officials were talking to these men they were told this man had used foul language to them.
They told them that, yes.
Is that not sufficient justification?
It is not.
Are you suggesting then that the men were telling lies?

I am not suggesting they were telling lies. It would not be fair to condemn the head labourer behind his back. The men admitted to the two senior officials sent to investigate that not a single word to which exception could be taken had been used by this man during those six or seven days and the forester tells me that the same is true of the period right up to the strike. I appeal to Deputy Dunne to urge these men to go back to work. Their present attitude is not helping the forestry drive. I am not anxious to stand over any head labourer who is unfair or harsh to his workers or uses bad language to them.
Are you not doing it now?
I am not doing it. I have had a report from the two officials I sent down. I cannot go down to investigate it myself.
Has any effort been made by the Minister's officials to clear this matter up rather than bring it in here for public discussion?
I will do something now that Irishmen are famous for the world over; I will answer that question by asking another one. What more can I do than I have done?

If a complaint has been made that this man is using unparliamentary language to his men, the only way in which to clear the matter up is to have responsible officials of the Minister's Department meet Deputy Dunne to discover whether or not these charges are justified rather than waste the time of the House without any approach to finality.
It was proved to the Minister.
Evidently not in such a way that he could understand it.
The House can go home if it likes. I will bring the matter into the open.
The men assured the officials sent down to investigate that not one objectionable word had passed this man's lips following on their resumption of work.
The issue is that this man had been using foul language. That had been proved to the Minister and it cannot be denied.
The Dáil adjourned at 10.55 p.m. until 3 o'clock on Wednesday, 28th February, 1951.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answer. - Lime and Fertiliser.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will state the number of applications received under the lime and fertiliser section of the land project; (2) the amount paid by farmers in application fees; (3) the number of loans granted; (4) the number of acres which have been limed and fertilised under the scheme, and (5) the amount expended on the purchase and distribution of lime and fertilisers.

I would refer the Deputy to a reply to a question from Deputy Maguire on the 7th March last in connection with statistics of progress under the land project. I undertook that comprehensive returns would be furnished periodically to Dáil Éireann, and the Deputy will recollect that two such returns have been supplied, the latest in November last. A further return is in preparation and will be available to Deputies within the next few weeks. It will include information relating to the recent extension of the project, i.e., the fertilisers scheme. I trust that this return will give the Deputy the information he requires. If it does not, I will have the Deputy supplied with whatever supplementary information he asks for.
